content.webTitle: Slade: Live at the BBC | CD review

fields.headline: Slade: Live at the BBC
fields.bodyText: It must be getting harder to find new Slade material to trudge out every Christmas but this is a treat, tracing the Black Country rockers' fascinating 1969-72 progress from a band Tony Blackburn introduces as "the skinhead set" to the biggest pop phenomenon since Beatlemania. These long-lost radio sessions give some feeling of how they arrived in the peace'n'love era like a force-10 gale, with Radio 2's Jimmy Young commenting he'd "never heard such a row in my life." Initially a "travelling jukebox" giving garage-punk-meets-psychedelic-rock treatments to songs from everyone from Fairport Convention to Janis Joplin, other tracks hint at what was to come. The second CD - a live broadcast in London - captures a band at the peak of their glam stomp, romping through Mama Weer All Crazee Now and the rest - with a roadie sitting in front of the drum kit to stop it moving - about to inspire everyone from the Sex Pistols to Oasis.
